meeting_context:
# North Star & Strategic Context

This file combines the overall project mission (North Star) and summaries of key strategic documents for use in AI prompts, particularly for the AI Agent Council context generation.

**Last Updated:** December 2025

---

**North Star:**
To build the most reliable, developer-friendly open-source AI agent framework and cloud platform—enabling builders worldwide to deploy autonomous agents that work seamlessly across chains and platforms. We create infrastructure where agents and humans collaborate, forming the foundation for a decentralized AI economy that accelerates the path toward beneficial AGI.

---

**Core Principles:**
1. **Execution Excellence** - Reliability and seamless UX over feature quantity
2. **Developer First** - Great DX attracts builders; builders create ecosystem value
3. **Open & Composable** - Multi-agent systems that interoperate across platforms
4. **Trust Through Shipping** - Build community confidence through consistent delivery

---

**Current Product Focus (Dec 2025):**
- **ElizaOS Framework** (v1.6.x) - The core TypeScript toolkit for building persistent, interoperable agents
- **ElizaOS Cloud** - Managed deployment platform with integrated storage and cross-chain capabilities
- **Flagship Agents** - Reference implementations (Eli5, Otaku) demonstrating platform capabilities
- **Cross-Chain Infrastructure** - Native support for multi-chain agent operations via Jeju/x402

---

**ElizaOS Mission Summary:**
ElizaOS is an open-source "operating system for AI agents" aimed at decentralizing AI development. Built on three pillars: 1) The Eliza Framework (TypeScript toolkit for persistent agents), 2) AI-Enhanced Governance (building toward autonomous DAOs), and 3) Eliza Labs (R&D driving cloud, cross-chain, and multi-agent capabilities). The native token coordinates the ecosystem. The vision is an intelligent internet built on open protocols and collaboration.

---

**Taming Information Summary:**
Addresses the challenge of information scattered across platforms (Discord, GitHub, X). Uses AI agents as "bridges" to collect, wrangle (summarize/tag), and distribute information in various formats (JSON, MD, RSS, dashboards, council episodes). Treats documentation as a first-class citizen to empower AI assistants and streamline community operations.
monthly_goal: December 2025: Execution excellence—complete token migration with high success rate, launch ElizaOS Cloud, stabilize flagship agents, and build developer trust through reliability and clear documentation.
daily_focus: Operational signal is dominated by trust risk: migration confusion and unanswered user questions are rising while Cloud UX gating/credits and core reliability work compete for priority.

key_points.summary: Community traffic continues to surface migration blockers (wallet compatibility, post-snapshot purchases, missing tokens) with several key questions left unanswered in public channels, increasing support load and reputational risk during the execution-excellence push.

deliberation_items.text: Do we treat token-migration support as a release-blocker workstream with named owners and SLA, or continue handling it opportunistically via moderators/DMs?
context: 💬-discussion (2026-01-02): "What will happen to Ai16z tokens bought after snapshot? Can they be migrated?" (Doho Felipe) — Unanswered
💬-discussion (2026-01-02): Pete offered help via DM for Phantom migration issues (Pete → Doho Felipe)

answer_1.text: Make migration support a release-blocker with a dedicated on-call rotation and public SLA.
answer_1.implication: Maximizes trust-through-shipping and reduces rumor-driven churn, but diverts core engineering cycles.

answer_2.text: Keep community-led support, but publish a single canonical migration FAQ and escalation form.
answer_2.implication: Improves clarity with minimal engineering overhead, but complex edge cases may still linger.

answer_3.text: Defer broad support until Cloud launch; respond only to critical incidents.
answer_3.implication: Protects build velocity short-term but risks compounding trust damage at the exact moment we need credibility.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: What is the Council’s stance on post-snapshot purchase eligibility and how aggressively do we communicate it to prevent ongoing uncertainty?
context: 💬-discussion (2026-01-02): "What will happen to Ai16z tokens bought after snapshot?" (Doho Felipe) — Unanswered
elizaOS Discord - 2025-12-31: "migration ends in February" (community Q&A)

answer_1.text: Explicitly disallow post-snapshot eligibility; communicate hard rules and remediation options (if any).
answer_1.implication: Creates clarity and reduces support noise, but may cause backlash from late buyers.

answer_2.text: Allow a limited amnesty window for post-snapshot purchases with additional verification steps.
answer_2.implication: Protects goodwill but increases operational complexity and potential attack surface.

answer_3.text: Keep policy flexible while data is gathered; communicate only that cases are under review.
answer_3.implication: Avoids premature commitments but prolongs uncertainty and invites speculation.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: Which wallet-compatibility path should we prioritize to reduce migration friction (e.g., Phantom-only guidance vs adding WalletConnect/Tangem support)?
context: 💬-discussion (2026-01-02): "Add WalletConnect option or Tangem wallet support to migration site" (mentioned by NobleCryptoic)
elizaOS Discord - 2025-12-31: Workaround suggested—"import MetaMask EOA into Phantom" (Kenk)

answer_1.text: Implement WalletConnect/Tangem support on the migration site as a top priority.
answer_1.implication: Reduces friction at scale and signals professionalism, but requires security review and delivery time.

answer_2.text: Standardize on a recommended wallet path (Phantom) and improve step-by-step guides and tooling checks.
answer_2.implication: Fastest to execute and consistent, but leaves some users blocked and unhappy.

answer_3.text: Partner with wallet providers for co-supported migration flows and shared support burden.
answer_3.implication: Can accelerate compatibility while offloading support, but introduces coordination dependency.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

key_points.topic: Cloud/Public Agent Onboarding, Gating & UX Coherence
key_points.summary: A cluster of new product issues converges on first-time user experience: how public agents present to unauthenticated visitors, how many free messages/credits to allow, and how to improve chat summaries—this is directly tied to developer trust and Cloud conversion.

deliberation_items.text: What is our canonical public-agent onboarding funnel (unauth visitor → signed-in user → owner) and do we commit to the proposed three-state UI split now?
context: GitHub issue #6313 (borisudovicic): "There are three different states of interacting with public agents... should have a distinct UI."
GitHub issue #6312 (borisudovicic): "Limit messages for non-signed up user to ~2-3"

answer_1.text: Adopt the three-state UI model immediately and treat it as a core Cloud readiness item.
answer_1.implication: Creates a coherent funnel and reduces user confusion, but adds short-term UI implementation load.

answer_2.text: Implement only the message-limit gate first, then iterate on UI states after Cloud stabilizes.
answer_2.implication: Quickly controls costs/abuse, but risks a clumsy UX that still confuses visitors and hurts conversion.

answer_3.text: Defer both until we have analytics; keep current UI and focus purely on platform stability.
answer_3.implication: Maximizes engineering focus, but may squander inbound traffic and weaken perceived polish.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: How strict should our free-usage policy be (credits and free messages) to balance growth, abuse prevention, and cost control?
context: GitHub issue #6315 (borisudovicic): "Change free credits from $5 to $1"
GitHub issue #6312 (borisudovicic): "Limit messages for non-signed up user to ~2-3"

answer_1.text: Aggressively tighten: $1 free credits + 2–3 messages for unsigned users.
answer_1.implication: Controls burn and abuse quickly, but risks reducing viral adoption and first-impression delight.

answer_2.text: Moderate: keep $5 credits but enforce message limits and rate limits for unsigned users.
answer_2.implication: Preserves top-of-funnel experimentation while limiting worst abuse vectors.

answer_3.text: Growth-first: maintain generous credits/messages; invest in abuse detection instead.
answer_3.implication: Maximizes experimentation and sharing, but may incur significant costs and attract spam.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: Do we prioritize improving chat summaries (quality and usefulness) as a trust/retention feature, or treat it as cosmetic until core reliability is fully locked?
context: GitHub issue #6311 (borisudovicic): "Chat summaries don't really make much sense. Can we improve"
GitHub issue #6314 (borisudovicic): "Public agent cards should have chat number"

answer_1.text: Prioritize summary quality now; it directly impacts perceived intelligence and usability.
answer_1.implication: Improves UX and retention signals, but may require model/prompt iteration and evaluation time.

answer_2.text: Ship minimal fixes (formatting + key-point extraction) and add analytics like chat count first.
answer_2.implication: Delivers incremental UX value quickly while building instrumentation for later improvements.

answer_3.text: Defer summaries until after Cloud launch; focus strictly on reliability and onboarding gates.
answer_3.implication: Keeps roadmap tight but risks ongoing user confusion and weaker product differentiation.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

key_points.topic: Core Reliability & Developer Velocity (Workflows, Plugins, Streaming)
key_points.summary: Engineering signals show active effort on reliability primitives (multi-step workflows with retry logic, parameter extraction, singleShot parameter support) plus ongoing reviews of streaming work—these are foundational to 'execution excellence' and developer-first DX.

deliberation_items.text: Which reliability primitives should be treated as highest-priority for Cloud readiness: workflow retries/parameter extraction, streaming stability, or singleShot parameterization?
context: Discord community update (2026-01-02): "enhancing multi-step workflows with retry logic and parameter extraction"
core-devs (2026-01-02): "need to make singleShot support parameters to prevent action problems" (Odilitime → Stan ⚡)

answer_1.text: Prioritize workflow retries + parameter extraction as the backbone of autonomous execution.
answer_1.implication: Directly improves agent reliability on real tasks, strengthening our 'execution excellence' narrative.

answer_2.text: Prioritize streaming stability and completion of streaming-related PRs to harden real-time UX.
answer_2.implication: Makes agents feel responsive and modern, but may not solve core autonomy failure modes.

answer_3.text: Prioritize singleShot parameter support to stop action failures and unblock plugin behavior.
answer_3.implication: Targets a sharp reliability pain point quickly, improving developer trust with a small, focused fix.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: How do we prevent review bottlenecks (single reviewer fatigue/health) from slowing high-impact merges during the Cloud push?
context: core-devs (2026-01-02): "Stan reviewing PRs while dealing with laryngitis"
core-devs (2026-01-02): "Need reviews on documentation and open PRs" (Stan ⚡)

answer_1.text: Establish a rotating triage + review captains system with clear merge criteria.
answer_1.implication: Improves throughput and resilience, but requires process discipline and alignment across maintainers.

answer_2.text: Temporarily relax review requirements for low-risk areas (docs/chore), keep strict reviews for core runtime.
answer_2.implication: Maintains safety where it matters while reducing friction, but risks inconsistent quality norms.

answer_3.text: Freeze non-critical PR intake until a backlog burn-down is complete.
answer_3.implication: Clears the queue fast but may discourage community contribution and slow momentum.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.

deliberation_items.text: What is our official posture on plugin ecosystem expansion right now: accelerate new plugins (plugin-git) or consolidate and harden existing ones (plugin-github) for Cloud?
context: 💬-coders (2026-01-02): "working on updates to plugin-github and creating a plugin-git" (Odilitime)
💬-coders (2026-01-02): Contributor asked "which is the main codebase" and was pointed to plugin-github (Ilum → Odilitime)

answer_1.text: Consolidate: harden plugin-github and define Cloud plugin acceptance standards before expanding.
answer_1.implication: Improves reliability and DX consistency, strengthening trust, but may slow breadth of capabilities.

answer_2.text: Accelerate: ship plugin-git quickly to unlock more developer workflows and excitement.
answer_2.implication: Boosts ecosystem momentum, but increases surface area and maintenance burden during a critical period.

answer_3.text: Dual-track with a gating policy: allow new plugins only if they meet test/telemetry/security baselines.
answer_3.implication: Balances growth with quality, but requires immediate definition and enforcement of the baselines.

answer_4.text: Other / More discussion needed / None of the above.
